arm_group.description: NS infusion will be done during surgery.
DEX infusion will be done during surgery.

brief_summary.textblock:
To evaluate the efficacy of dexmedetomidine for the prevention of catheter-related bladder
      discomfort

detailed_description.textblock:
After transurethral bladder resection, large-sized foley catheter have been used for
      drainage of urine and residual blood. Because of urinary catheterization, patients usually
      experiences catheter-related bladder discomfort defined as a burning sensation with an urge
      to void or discomfort in the supra-pubic region caused by catheter- related bladder
      irritation.

      Dexmedetomidine is an alpha-2 antagonist and used as an analgesic agent. The investigators
      try to evaluate The efficacy of dexmedetomidine for the treatment of catheter-related
      bladder discomfort

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients scheduled for transurethral bladder resection

          -  ASA I-III

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Patient who disagrees to participate this investigation

          -  Patient with severe cardiovascular disease

          -  Patient with small-sized foley catheter (less than 18 Fr.)

          -  Patinets with any urinary tract obstructions

          -  Patient with hyperactive or neurogenic bladder

          -  Patients with chronic renal failure

          -  Patient with morbidly obese

          -  Patients with neurogenic disorder

          -  Patient with medications for chronic pain

intervention.description: Dexmedetomidine will be injected (1 mcg/kg for 10 minutes and afterward 0.3 mcg/kg/hr)
Normal saline will be infused during surgery

clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of Dexmedetomidine for the Therapy of Catheter-related Bladder Discomfort

primary_outcome.description: catheter-related bladder discomfort at postoperative 1 hour was evaluated as none, mild, moderate, severe. The number of patients with mild, moderate, severe discomfort will be calculated and compared between groups.
primary_outcome.measure: The number of patients with catheter-related bladder discomfort

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Catheter-related bladder discomfort will be evaluated as none, mild, moderate, severe at postoperative 0, 1, 6, 24 hours.
Pain at suprapubic area will be evaluated using NRS (0:none, 100:worst imaginable) at postoperative 0, 1, 6, 24 hours

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver), Primary Purpose: Prevention
